17/
Do you have a True Tale from IT? We’d love to hear it. Send it to us at sharky@compterworld.com

And you can read more true tales in our Shark Tank  -->
https://www.computerworld.com/blog/shark-tank/ …pic.twitter.com/1nj3ZD0v5u

1103132071554363392.text:
16/
The sales rep must have been true to his word, but so was the new leadership. 

The next day our IT hero received a short apology email from Barney, cc’ed to the rep’s VP and our IT hero’s VP.pic.twitter.com/2K4Fr9bbNY

1103131805446737921.text:
15/
Sales rep: This is unacceptable. I’ve been with the company for over 20 years. My VP is going to hear about how unhelpful you’ve been.pic.twitter.com/zyFEPWnA2r

1103131650056167424.text:
14/
IT hero: Not possible. Your only option is to take the laptop to the corporate facility and plug into the network. Best you get started. It’s already past noon.pic.twitter.com/HLgIVywK2F

1103131500759994368.text:
13/
Sales rep: I was too busy making the company money to mess with it.

IT hero: Changing your password takes less than a minute. 

Sales rep: Just fix it. I’m your customer and that’s what I expect.pic.twitter.com/k7aCODEHFe

1103131321294032899.text:
12/
… And I know that the mandatory annual training you received on using a laptop warned about not letting your password expire.pic.twitter.com/irI4gj9O7Z

1103131066020364293.text:
11/
… I know you’ve been getting reminder pop-ups every time you logged into your laptop and the VPN and anything else that used your corporate credentials. …pic.twitter.com/NzDnA3wuNI

1103130841750925312.text:
10/
… I also know these emails warned you that allowing the password to expire would require a hardwire connection to the corporate network. …pic.twitter.com/vLWPe2RIrG

1103130687832498176.text:
9/
IT hero: I know you’ve been getting daily warning emails for two weeks saying when your password was going to expire and how to change it. …pic.twitter.com/48XdGrktVk

1103130469456060416.text:
8/
IT hero: It’s expired on the laptop. The only way to fix it now is to plug into the corporate network. We can’t magically connect to your laptop from here. 

Sales rep: Stop with the technical gobbledygook, and just fix it.pic.twitter.com/8pP9LvJ6Ol

1103130252430245889.text:
7/
Sales rep: But that’s over two hours away. I have too much work to do to waste time driving. You need to do something.pic.twitter.com/4A0ifdwR2E

1103130056644329474.text:
6/
… The only way to reset your password is to physically connect your laptop to the corporate network using a network cable. You will need to drive to the nearest corporate facility.pic.twitter.com/3bnDXuEYwj

1103129881628602368.text:
5/
IT hero: (Knowing Barney works out of his house far from the nearest corporate-owned location.) I’m afraid I have some bad news. …pic.twitter.com/NBpFaPmrpx

1103129694222848001.text:
4/
IT hero: IT. How can I help you?

Sales rep: This is Barney Hatestek. I can’t get logged into my laptop. It says my password is expired.pic.twitter.com/VORleOWIag

1103128944088371201.text:
3/
But when new leadership is installed, it has a different take on the dynamic and gives IT permission to lay down the law with the problem children. The first interaction of the new era goes like this:pic.twitter.com/C5gWvidllz

1103128743122485248.text:
2/
The IT department has bent over backwards for years to accommodate older sales reps who can only be described as luddites. They see technology as a hindrance and IT workers as obstacles to their progress, to be berated and abused.pic.twitter.com/Vl1e80KYRE

1103128522313383936.text:
“My password has expired, and I can’t get into my laptop.” 

So began a IT support call that ended differently than you would expect. Follow along as we tell this true tale of an IT hero who stood their ground. #TrueTaleFromIT

(Thread 1/17)pic.twitter.com/r6bNA7Xtxh

13/ 
Do you have a True Tale from IT? We’d love to hear it. Send it to us at sharky@compterworld.com

And you can read more true tales in our Shark Tank  https://www.computerworld.com/blog/shark-tank/ …
#TrueTalesFromIT #SharkTankpic.twitter.com/fhjhER8RTx

1098058670196305921.text:
12/ 
"And for me and our internet security manager, it became our little secret."pic.twitter.com/x1QQffQhoA

1098058518358306817.text:
11/ 
"So much for policy -- No apology, at least to me, and it was never spoken of again by the CEO,” our IT hero said.pic.twitter.com/UsUpJIETWb

1098058284731432960.text: 10/ It doesn't take him long to determine that something has been hacked -- but it's the CEO's browser, as a result of the CEO's son using this work laptop to look at some questionable websites.pic.twitter.com/NH25N9QfQq

1098057939527651330.text: 9/ Finally, the security manager decides it's time to make a visit to the CEO's office to get a firsthand look at the hacking the boss has observed.pic.twitter.com/ltlSHc2rYc

1098057727660707840.text: 8/ The internet security manager has the same experience -- no indication of hacking. He digs deeper into the server logs. But he can't even find evidence of attempts at hacking the website.pic.twitter.com/Yy8h0IMv58

1098057358142595078.text: 7/ He tries viewing a few other pages. Still nothing. Navigating back to the home page, he clears his browser's cache and cookies and tries again. But it looks just the same as before.pic.twitter.com/BflSG11XK3

1098057118740033536.text: 6/ Our IT hero immediately opens his browser and goes to the company's home page. But he can't find the hackers' text and images -- or any other sign that anything is wrong.pic.twitter.com/p1YEPU9SW8

1098056819703009283.text: 5/ The big boss knows this is the case because there are spammy images and text on the home page, among other issues. Not surprisingly, the CEO is adamant that this must be resolved ASAP.pic.twitter.com/e4h0L9F6Kt

1098056413253980162.text: 4/ "After arriving at work one morning, I opened my email to find a frantic message from our CEO to me and our internet security manager, stating that our website had been hacked," he said.pic.twitter.com/Ars1UUl3Fo

1098056090070249473.text: 3/ Like most corporations, his company had a policy that computers and laptops were to be used only for company business, along with policies governing the appropriate use of the internet in the work environment.pic.twitter.com/L4BEOwoas1

1098055895060279297.text:
2/ A True Tale from IT – 
It's a few years after Y2K, and this IT pro has overall responsibility for all things related to his company's website.pic.twitter.com/D4sHreU78g

1098055653921308678.text:
“Our website has been hacked!” the CEO said. And the good folks in IT believed him until … #TrueTaleFromIT 
(Thread 1/13)pic.twitter.com/Pa9iBEIGom
